perc_income_min_price_25.long_description: The minimum price for good internet (25 MB/s upload) as a percentage of median household income.

perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.short_name: Households with cable, fiber optic, or DSL
perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.long_name: Percentage of households with a high speed internet service (cable, fiber optic, or DSL)
perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.short_description: Percentage of households self-reported to have a high speed internet service (cable, fiber optic, or DSL)
perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.long_description: Percentage of households self-reported to have a high speed internet service. A high speed internet service is defined as a cable, fiber optic, or DSL internet connection. Based on American Community Survey Table B28002 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.statement: {value} of households in {features.name} have a cable, fiber optic, or DSL internet connection.

perc_hh_with_broadband.long_description: Percentage of households self-reported to have a broadband internet connection. Broadband internet is defined as any type of internet other than a dial-up. Based on American Community Survey Table B28002 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
perc_hh_with_broadband.statement: {value} of households in {features.name} have a broadband connection.

avg_up_using_devices.short_description: Average upload speed weighted by number of devices.
avg_up_using_devices.statement: The average upload speed is {value} in {features.name}.

median_read_pass_rate.long_name: Median percentage of 3rd graders passing reading test

median_read_pass_rate.long_description: Median percentage of 3rd grade population passing reading test. The median is calculated across schools in the region.
median_read_pass_rate.statement: On average, {value} of 3rd graders pass reading in {region_name}.

acs_postsecondary_percent.long_name: Estimated Percentage of Population With Any Postsecondary Education
acs_postsecondary_percent.short_description: Percentage of the population who reported any postsecondary education.
acs_postsecondary_percent.long_description: Percentage of the population who reported any postsecondary education, according to the U.S. Census American Community Survey 5-year estimates.
acs_postsecondary_percent.statement: {value} of those in {region_name} report any postsecondary education.

sources.name: U.S. Census, American Community Survey
sources.location: 5-Year estimates, table B06009, via the API

schools_2year_with_science_program_per_1.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with science programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
schools_2year_with_science_program_per_1.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 41) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 41, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_with_science_program_per_1.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a science program per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics and Completions files

schools_2year_with_physical_program_per_.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with physical science programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
schools_2year_with_physical_program_per_.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with physical science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 40) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 40, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_with_physical_program_per_.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a physical science program per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics and Completions files

schools_under2year_min_drivetime.short_description: Drive time to the nearest <2-year schools.
schools_under2year_min_drivetime.long_description: Minimal drive time to a schools authorized to award certificates that are typically obtained in less than 2 years from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
schools_under2year_min_drivetime.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a <2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

Catchment areas were calculated using (a) <2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.

daycare_under_10_per_1k.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 10
daycare_under_10_per_1k.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age.
daycare_under_10_per_1k.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 10 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
daycare_under_10_per_1k.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

daycare_over_4_per_1k.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
daycare_over_4_per_1k.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.
daycare_over_4_per_1k.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
daycare_over_4_per_1k.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

daycare_per_1k.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
daycare_per_1k.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
daycare_per_1k.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
daycare_per_1k.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

daycare_min_drivetime.short_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider.
daycare_min_drivetime.long_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider of any type.
daycare_min_drivetime.statement: It takes {value} to drive to the nearest day care provider in {region_name}.

daycare_capacity.short_description: Summed capacity (seats) of all day care providers within the region.
daycare_capacity.long_description: Summed capacity (seats) of all day care providers within the region.

earnings_per_job.long_description: Earnings per job is calculated based on the GDP and Personal Income table from the Bureau of Economic Analysis.

median_household_income.long_description: Self-reported median household income in the past 12 months (in 2019 inflation adjusted-dollars. Based on the American Community Survey Table B19013 ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
median_household_income.short_description: Self-reported median household income in the past 12 months (in 2019 inflation adjusted-dollars.
median_household_income.statement: The median household income in {features.name} is {value} per year.

emp_rate.short_description: Population self-reported as employed as a percentage of total civilian workforce population.
emp_rate.long_description: Population self-reported as employed as a percentage of total civilian workforce population. Based on American Community Survey Table B23025 ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
emp_rate.statement: {value} of the population in {features.name} is employed.

percent_food_insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the percent of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
percent_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated percentage of total people in food insecure households
percent_food_insecure.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
percent_food_insecure.statement: {value} percent of the population in {features.name} are food insecure.

number_food_insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the number of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
number_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated number of total people in food insecure households
number_food_insecure.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).

Cost_Per_Meal.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
Cost_Per_Meal.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
Cost_Per_Meal.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

Num_Child_Food_Insecure.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.statement: The population of food insecure children in {features.name} is {value}.

Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

no_hlth_ins_pct.long_name: Percent of population without health insurance
no_hlth_ins_pct.short_description: Percent of the population (ages 19-64) self-reported to not be currently covered by any type of health insurance or health coverage plan
no_hlth_ins_pct.long_description: Percent of the population self-reported to not be currently covered by any type of health insurance or health coverage plan. Based on American Community Survey Tables B27010 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
no_hlth_ins_pct.statement: {value} of the population does not have health insurance in {features.name}.

prevent_hosp_rate.long_name: Preventable hospital stays per 100,000 Medicare enrollees
prevent_hosp_rate.short_description: Rate of hospital stays for ambulatory-care sensitive conditions per 100,000 Medicare enrollees
prevent_hosp_rate.long_description: Rate of hospital stays for ambulatory-care sensitive conditions per 100,000 Medicare enrollees. Ambulatory care refers to diagnoses that are usually treatable in outpatient settings. This data is based on Medicare claims and comes from County Health Rankings.
prevent_hosp_rate.statement: {value} of the hospitalizations in {features.name} were preventable (due to conditions usually treated in outpatient settings).

avg_monthly_rate.category: Behavioral Health, Substance Use Disorder and Recovery
avg_monthly_rate.short_name: Monthly average ED visits for drug overdose
avg_monthly_rate.long_name: Monthly average emergency department visits for drug overdose rate per 100,000 residents
avg_monthly_rate.short_description: Monthly average emergency department visits for drug overdose per 100,000 residents.
avg_monthly_rate.long_description: Monthly average emergency department visits for drug overdose per 100,000 residents.
avg_monthly_rate.statement: The average emergency department visits for drug overdose rate in {features.name} is {value}.

inadequate.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Inadequate
inadequate.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Inadequate
inadequate.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of inadequate. Inadequate levels occurs when prenatal care begins in the 5th month or later or no prenatal care, regardless of the number of visits or, with less than 50% or more recommended visits received from 1st through 4th month.  The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
inadequate.statement: There are {value} cases rated as inadequate in {features.name}.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

intermediate.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Intermediate
intermediate.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Intermediate
intermediate.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of intermediate. Intermediate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month, and the proportion of the number of visits is between 50-79%.   The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
intermediate.statement: There are {value} cases rated as intermediate in {features.name}.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

adequate.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Adequate
adequate.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Adequate
adequate.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of adequate. Adequate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is between 80% and 109%. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
adequate.statement: There are {value} cases rated as adequate in {features.name}.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

adequateplus.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Adequate Plus
adequateplus.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Adequate Plus
adequateplus.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of adequate plus.  Adequate Plus  prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is  110% or more. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
adequateplus.statement: There are {value} cases rated as adequate plus in {features.name}.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

inadequate_pc.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Inadequate
inadequate_pc.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Inadequate
inadequate_pc.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of inadequate. Proportion of pregnant mothers receiving inadequate prenatal care. Inadequate levels occurs when prenatal care begins in the 5th month or later or no prenatal care, regardless of the number of visits or, with less than 50% or more recommended visits received from 1st through 4th month.  The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
inadequate_pc.statement: {value} of the cases in {features.name} rated as inadequate.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

intermediate_pc.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Intermediate
intermediate_pc.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Intermediate
intermediate_pc.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of intermediate. Proportion of pregnant mothers receiving intermediate prenatal care. Intermediate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month, and the proportion of the number of visits is between 50-79%.   The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
intermediate_pc.statement: {value} of the cases in {features.name} rated as intermediate.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

adequate_pc.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Adequate
adequate_pc.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Adequate
adequate_pc.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of adequate. Proportion of pregnant mothers receiving adequate prenatal care.  Adequate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is between 80% and 109%. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
adequate_pc.statement: {value} of the cases in {features.name} rated as adequate.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

adequateplus_pc.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Adequate Plus
adequateplus_pc.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Adequate Plus
adequateplus_pc.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of adequate plus.  Proportion of pregnant mothers receiving prenatal care beyond adequate levels. Adequate Plus  prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is  110% or more. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
adequateplus_pc.statement: {value} of the cases in {features.name} rated as adequate plus.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

perc_poor_phys_hlth_days_14_and_over.short_description: Percent of the population self-reporting poor physical health
perc_poor_phys_hlth_days_14_and_over.long_description: Percent of the population self-reporting poor physical health in over 14 days of the previous month. Based on the Virginia Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance Survey.
perc_poor_phys_hlth_days_14_and_over.statement: {value} of the population in {features.name} reports poor physical health.

sources.name: Virginia Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System

perc_poor_ment_hlth_days_14_and_over.short_description: Percent of the population self-reporting poor mental health
perc_poor_ment_hlth_days_14_and_over.long_description: Percent of the population self-reporting poor mental health in over 14 days of the previous month. Based on the Virginia Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance Survey.
perc_poor_ment_hlth_days_14_and_over.statement: {value} of the population in {features.name} reports poor mental health.

sources.name: Virginia Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System

access_care_indicator.short_description: Whether community members have access to a primary care physician and the means to pay for care..
access_care_indicator.long_description: Whether community members have access to a primary care physician and the means to pay for care. It includes the proportion of uninsured residents and the number of physicians within 30 miles of the community.
access_care_indicator.statement: The access to care indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

community_environment_indicator.short_description: A measure of the natural, built and social environment of a community.
community_environment_indicator.long_description: A measure of the natural, built and social environment of a community. It includes the air quality indicator, the population churning indicator, the population density indicator, and the walkability indicator.
community_environment_indicator.statement: The community environmental profile in {features.name} is {value}.

air_quality_indicator.short_description: Includes EPA measures of pollution, including on-road, non-road and non-point pollution, and EPA measures of neurological, cancer and respiration risk..
air_quality_indicator.long_description: Includes EPA measures of pollution, including on-road, non-road and non-point pollution, and EPA measures of neurological, cancer and respiration risk.
air_quality_indicator.statement: The air quality indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

affordability_indicator.short_description: The proportion of a communitys income spent on housing and transportation.
affordability_indicator.long_description: The proportion of a communitys income spent on housing and transportation. This indicates how much income remains for other priorities, including food, health care and social activities.

consumer_opportunity_indicator.short_description: A measure of the consumer resources available within a community.
consumer_opportunity_indicator.long_description: A measure of the consumer resources available within a community. It includes the affordability indicator, the education indicator, the food accessbility indicator, and the material deprevation indicator.
consumer_opportunity_indicator.statement: The consumer opportunity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

wellness_disparity_indicator.short_description: A measure of the disparate access to health services within a community.
wellness_disparity_indicator.long_description: A measure of the disparate access to health services within a community. It includes the access to care indicator and the segregation indicator.
wellness_disparity_indicator.statement: The wellness disparity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

walkability_indicator.short_description: A measure of how walkable a community is.
walkability_indicator.long_description: A measure of how walkable a community is based on residential and employment density, land use (destination) diversity, street connectivity and public transit accessibility.

segregation_indicator.short_description: A measure of whether and how much people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds live together in diverse communities.
segregation_indicator.long_description: A measure of whether and how much people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds live together in diverse communities. It includes measures of both community diversity and the distance between communities with different racial or ethnic profiles.

pop_density_indicator.short_description: A measure of population density that takes into account the density levels most people in the community experience.
pop_density_indicator.long_description: A measure of population density that takes into account the density levels most people in the community experience.
pop_density_indicator.statement: The population density indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

pop_churning_indicator.short_description: The amount of population turnover within a community.
pop_churning_indicator.long_description: The amount of population turnover within a community. It measure the rate at which people both move into a community and move out of a community.
pop_churning_indicator.statement: The population churning index in {features.name} is {value}.

material_deprivation_indicator.short_description: Based on the Towsend Material Deprivation Index, it examines the private material resources available to households in a community.
material_deprivation_indicator.long_description: Based on the Towsend Material Deprivation Index, it examines the private material resources available to households in a community. 4 indicators make up Towsend: overcrowding (>2 persons per room), unemployment, % of persons no vehicle or car, and % of person who rent.
material_deprivation_indicator.statement: The material deprivation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

job_participation_indicator.short_description: The percentage of individuals 16-64 years of age active in the civilian labor force.
job_participation_indicator.long_description: The percentage of individuals 16-64 years of age active in the civilian labor force. It includes both those currently working and those seeking work.
job_participation_indicator.statement: The job participation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

income_inequality_indicator.short_description: The Gini Index, a common measure of income inequality.
income_inequality_indicator.long_description: The Gini Index, a common measure of income inequality, measures whether the income earned within a community is distributed broadly or concentrated within the hands of small number of households.
income_inequality_indicator.statement: The income inequality index in {features.name} is {value}.

health_opportunity_indicator.short_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives.
health_opportunity_indicator.long_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives based on the Social Determinants of Health. It is a hierarchical index that allows users to examine social determinants of health at multiple levels of detail in Virginia. It is made up of over 30 variables, combined into 13 indicators, grouped into four profiles, which are aggregated into a single Health Opportunity Index. The HOI is reported at both the census tract and county/independent city level.
health_opportunity_indicator.statement: The health opportunity index in {features.name} is {value}.

food_accessibility_indicator.short_description: A measure of access to food by low income people within a community.
food_accessibility_indicator.long_description: A measure of access to food by low income people within a community. It measures the proportion of the low income community that has a large grocery store within 1 mile in urban areas or 10 miles in rural areas.
food_accessibility_indicator.statement: The food accessibility indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

employment_access_indicator.short_description: A measure of the number of jobs accessible to members of the community.
employment_access_indicator.long_description: A measure of the number of jobs accessible to members of the community. Accessibility is determined by distance: close jobs are more accessible than jobs farther away.
employment_access_indicator.statement: The employment accessibility indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

education_indicator.short_description: The average number of years of schooling among adults in the community.
education_indicator.long_description: The average number of years of schooling among adults in the community. It can range from zero (those with no formal schooling) to 20 (those with a doctorate/professional degree).

economic_opportunity_indicator.short_description: A measure of the economic opportunities available within a community.
economic_opportunity_indicator.long_description: A measure of the economic opportunities available within a community. Includes the employment accessibility indicator, the income inequality indicator, and the job participation indicator.
economic_opportunity_indicator.statement: The economic opportunity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

primcare_3sfca.long_name: Primary care geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
primcare_3sfca.short_description: Index of primary care physician availability based on supply and demand of providers
primcare_3sfca.long_description: Primary care availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of physicians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for physicians (population served by physicians). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
primcare_3sfca.statement: The primary care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

primcare_cnt.short_description: Count of primary care physicians based on provider locations
primcare_cnt.long_description: Count of primary care physicians based on provider locations. Address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
primcare_cnt.statement: There are {value} primary care physicians in {features.name}.

ped_3sfca.long_name: Pediatric care geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
ped_3sfca.short_description: Index of pediatric care physician availability based on supply and demand of providers
ped_3sfca.long_description: Pediatric care availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of pediatricians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for pediatricians (population under 16). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
ped_3sfca.statement: The pediatric care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

ped_cnt.short_description: Count of pediatricians based on provider locations
ped_cnt.long_description: Count of pediatricians based on provider locations. Address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.

obgyn_3sfca.long_name: OBGYN care geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
obgyn_3sfca.short_description: Index of OBGYN care availability based on supply and demand of providers
obgyn_3sfca.long_description: OBGYN care availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of OBGYNs per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for OBGYNs (population served by OBGYNs). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online physician directory.

obgyn_cnt.short_description: Count of OBGYNs based on provider locations
obgyn_cnt.long_description: Count of OBGYN care providers based on provider locations. Address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.

mental_3sfca.long_name: Mental health services geographic availability (3-step  floating catchment areas)
mental_3sfca.short_description: Index of mental health services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
mental_3sfca.long_description: Mental health services availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
mental_3sfca.statement: The mental health services availability for {features.name} is {value}.

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

mental_cnt.long_name: Availability of mental health services by count
mental_cnt.short_description: Count of mental health facilities based on facility locations
mental_cnt.long_description: Count of mental health facilities based on facility locations. Location data were collected from the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) repository.
mental_cnt.statement: There are {value} mental health facilities in {features.name}.

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

mental_near_10_median.long_name: Mental health availability by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
mental_near_10_median.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest mental health facilities
mental_near_10_median.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest mental health facilities. Facility location data were collected from the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) repository. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
mental_near_10_median.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest mental health facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

ems_3sfca.long_name: Emergency medical services geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
ems_3sfca.short_description: Index of emergency medical services availability based on supply and demand of facilities
ems_3sfca.long_description: Emergency medical services availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
ems_3sfca.statement: The emergency medical services availability for {features.name} is {value}.

ems_cnt.long_name: Availability of emergency medical services by count
ems_cnt.short_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations
ems_cnt.long_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository.
ems_cnt.statement: There are {value} emergency medical services facilities in {features.name}.

ems_near_10_median.long_name: Emergency medical services availability by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
ems_near_10_median.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities
ems_near_10_median.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities. Facility location data were collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
ems_near_10_median.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest emergency medical service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

subs_3sfca.short_name: Substance use/behavioral health services geographic availability
subs_3sfca.long_name: Substance use/behavioral health services geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
subs_3sfca.short_description: Index of substance use/behavioral health services availability based on supply and demand of facilities
subs_3sfca.long_description: Substance use/behavioral health services availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
subs_3sfca.statement: The substance use/behavioral health services availability for {features.name} is {value}.

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

subs_cnt.long_name: Availability of substance use/behavioral health by count
subs_cnt.short_description: Count of substance use/behavioral health facilities based on facility locations
subs_cnt.long_description: Count of substance use/behavioral health facilities based on facility locations. Location data were collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository.
subs_cnt.statement: There are {value} substance use facilities in {features.name}.

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

subs_near_10_median.short_name: Substance use/behavioral health services availability (drive time)
subs_near_10_median.long_name: Substance use/behavioral health services availability by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
subs_near_10_median.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest substance use/behavioral health services facilities
subs_near_10_median.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest substance use/behavioral health services facilities. Facility location data were collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
subs_near_10_median.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest substance use/behavioral health service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

dent_e2sfca.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
dent_e2sfca.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
dent_e2sfca.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
dent_e2sfca.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

dent_cnt.short_description: Count of dentists based on provider locations
dent_cnt.long_description: Count of dentists based on provider locations. Address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.

lou04.title: Using a gis-based floating catchment method to assess areas with shortage of physicians

lou09.title: An enhanced two-step floating catchment area (e2sfca) method for measuring spatial accessibility to primary care physicians

lou03.title: Measures of spatial accessibility to health care in a gis environment: synthesis and a case study in the Chicago region

perc_afr_amer_alone.long_description: The Black population percent. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates Table B01001.
perc_afr_amer_alone.short_description: The Black population population percent. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.

perc_AAPI.long_description: The Asian American/Pacific Islander population percent. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates Table B01001.
perc_AAPI.short_description: The Asian American/Pacific Islander population population percent. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
perc_AAPI.statement: The Asian American/Pacific Islander population is {value} in {features.name}.

perc_hispanic_or_latino.long_description: The Hispanic/Latino population percent. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates Table B01001.
perc_hispanic_or_latino.short_description: The Hispanic/Latino population population percent. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.

perc_wht_alone.long_description: The White population percent. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates Table B01001.
perc_wht_alone.short_description: The White population population percent. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.

perc_native_alone.long_description: The Native population percent. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates Table B01001.
perc_native_alone.short_description: The Native population population percent. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.

perc_female.long_description: The percent of females in the total population. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2010/2021 5-year estimates table S0101.
perc_female.short_description: The percent of females in population. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2010/2021 5-year estimates.

perc_male.long_description: The percent of males in the total population. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2010/2021 5-year estimates table S0101.
perc_male.short_description: The percent of males in population. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2010/2021 5-year estimates.

perc_pop_under_20.long_description: The percent of the population under age 20. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates Table B01001.
perc_pop_under_20.short_description: The percent of the population under age 20. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
perc_pop_under_20.statement: The percent of the population under age 20 is {value} in {features.name}.

perc_pop_65_plus.long_description: The percent of the population over age 64. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates Table B01001.
perc_pop_65_plus.short_description: The percent of the population over age 64. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
perc_pop_65_plus.statement: The percent of the population over age 64 is {value} in {features.name}.

perc_pop_20_64.long_description: The percent of the population between age 20 and 64. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates Table B01001.
perc_pop_20_64.short_description: The percent of the population between age 20 and 64. Based on American Community Survey ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
perc_pop_20_64.statement: The percent of the population between age 20 and 64 is {value} in {features.name}.
